Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Interactive Gesture-Based Data Manipulation and Visualization for Exploratory Learning and Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Visual exploration and analysis of data is increasingly important for advancement in virtually every area of human endeavor. Whether recorded directly by people or indirectly using machines, data captures our observations and interpretations of the world. When people interact with data, it is almost always in a visual form like graphics or text. The goal of this project is to vastly expand the usefulness of interactive visualizations by providing a general way to create and edit data inside the visualizations themselves. The key new idea of the project is that visualization users can perform sequences of gestures with common input devices to express their observations and interpretations directly in visual form. The visualizations not only show data, but also serve as meaningful graphical spaces in which to edit that data. By extending the data processing workflows and display techniques that are currently used in popular visualization tools and software libraries, we can flexibly and expressively translate the details of interactions into precise data changes with simultaneous visual feedback.

The innovative contributions of the project will include a general method to support interactive data editing in visualizations, a diverse collection of data editing gestures, a set of patterns to guide the process of designing visualization tools with data editing features, a declarative programming language for quickly building those tools, and a variety of built tools that show off real applications of data editing in visualizations. The project focuses on developing, evaluating, and distributing tools for scholarly research in the digital humanities. It tightly integrates education to bring together students and researchers from computer science, information science, and the humanities, and provide them with concrete opportunities to engage in authentic interdisciplinary collaboration. Scholarly research and education in the humanities involves open-ended exploration, analysis, and interpretation of complex data sets in diverse areas of study. This makes it an exemplary first target to demonstrate how gesture-based visual editing can be broadly applied to data analysis in virtually every segment of society. The broader impacts of the project will spring from the availability of a new, foundational, general-purpose methodology to support data entry, organization, annotation, and correction. Project products will include publications, tutorials, videos, the visualization gesture system as open source software, a compendium of data editing gestures, and a gallery of demonstration visualization tools for public download. Information on the project and resulting resources can be accessed on the project web site (http://www.cs.ou.edu/~weaver/nsf-career/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chris Weaver has completed research and education development on "Interactive Gesture-Based Data Manipulation and Visualization for Exploratory Learning and Research" supported by an NSF/IIS/CISE CAREER award. Over the course of the funding period, he worked at the University of Oklahoma (OU) with students in the Computer Science (CS) and Data Science & Analytics (DSA) graduate programs, and with faculty collaborators in the School of Library & Information Science (SLIS) and the Department of the History of Science, Technology and Medicine (HSTM). Weaver is a computer scientist who works broadly in visual analytics and visualization systems, and has a particular interest in applications of visualization in the digital humanities. In this project he specifically focused on developing interactive visual data editing approaches to support open-ended observation, reasoning, and interpretation in digital humanities learning and scholarship.

With the assistance of graduate students and through extensive interaction with collaborators, Weaver pursued multiple threads of research and education development within the scope of the project. Major threads of research included conducting a survey of known forms of interaction used in visualization user interfaces, developing a formal model for describing visual data editing gestures, developing a user input processing framework for mapping interactions into geometric objects and relationships, exploring the design space of geometric data editing interactions, developing a software architecture and language for programming data editing gestures, growing an extensive gallery of example gestures for common and exotic application uses, and implementing data editing gestures in his Improvise visualization system and in humanities-related visualizations created using it. Educational development focused on creating a series of hands-on assignments for learning about and reflecting on data stewardship and visualization in the OU SLIS course on Organization of Information and Knowledge Resources using several of the visualizations. The assignments were completed by more than 60 students in the course over three semesters.

Visualizations often represent data using a mix of position, size, shape, color, and other graphical characteristics. We found that geometry is central to the design of visual data editing interactions, even for editing data attributes that are represented non-geometrically, such as with color. Gestures themselves can be composed of one or more interactions to "draw" geometries whose properties are then translated into data values. The kinds of geometric objects made available for interactive manipulation in a visualization can be common, unusual, or even exotic. The multitude of relationships between the geometries can be organized into a "geometrie" hierarchy that meaningfully prioritizes them based on their familiarity and importance, providing a basis for visualization designers to select appropriate combinations of geometric objects, relationships, and properties for particular data editing needs. Each visualization itself offers additional, contextual geometry that can be incorporated into gesture designs. Our gesture gallery exemplifies many such designs. Although most visualizations up to now support basic navigation over the data, and many also support selection of data subsets to highlight, few support actual data editing directly inside themselves. Our results point to a vast and diverse design space of gestures for editing data directly within visualizations, a space that is ripe for exploration by visualization researchers, practitioners, and end-users.

Over the course of the project, Weaver worked with over 15 graduate research assistants, thesis advisees, and independent study students on topics within or overlapping the above research threads. Weaver also visited visualization researchers in the VRVis group at the University of Vienna while on sabbatical to complete the formal model of gesture specification. His outreach beyond the visualization community included invited talks and panels to present the project and outcomes at several of the Workshops of Visualization for Digital Humanities (VIS4DH), the Annual Convention of the Modern Language Association, the Humanities Data Visualization Workshop at Georgia Tech, the Virtual Residency Intermediate Workshop hosted by the OU Supercomputing Center for Education & Research, the OU Data Science Working Group, the OU School of Meteorology, and the Konservatorium of the Institute for Computer Graphics and Algorithms at the Technical University of Vienna. He also spoke at the Round 4 Trans-Atlantic Platform Digging into Data Challenge end of grant conference held at NSF, offering experiences working on visualization projects with collaborators from different humanities disciplines and insights on how to successfully springboard into larger research and development projects like this one.
